awd_titl_txt: The iPlant Collaborative: Cyberinfrastructure for the Life Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
iPlant is a new kind of virtual organization, a cyberinfrastructure (CI) collaborative created to catalyze progress in computationally-based discovery in plant biology. iPlant has created a comprehensive and widely used CI, driven by community needs, and adopted by a number of large-scale informatics projects and thousands of individual users. The project has laid a strong foundation to build an increasingly more capable CI and is poised to have an even greater impact on the plant sciences and a number of related fields, with a new focus on addressing computational bottlenecks for a broad number of life science researchers.   

In the next five years, iPlant will continue to enhance the capabilities of a comprehensive CI and will also expand the scope to cover a number of new fields of inquiry. In iPlant's initial phase, Grand Challenge projects were defined to shape community requirements for the design of the CI. The two projects, Genotype-to-Phenotype and the Tree of Life, led to new analytical tools and competences for genomics and evolutionary biology. Future work will advance these capabilities and expand into capture and modeling of phenotypic, environmental, and ecological data. As before, this growth will be motivated by community needs and accomplished by community collaboration.   

iPlant will continue to actively partner with other large CI development efforts and will coordinate CI development where feasible, appropriate, and mutually beneficial. iPlant will continue to be the underlying infrastructure provider for a number of projects that provide a variety of bioinformatics services. While continuing to support plant biology discovery research, iPlant will expand scope beyond the plant sciences, in coordination with nascent animal-centered efforts. The project will continue to adapt to the rapidly changing needs of the life sciences community and the rapidly changing technological landscape faced by researchers.   

The intellectual merit of the project is in advancing the state of modern biology. Without question, research progress in the plant sciences, and in life sciences more generally, is increasingly limited by data and computational challenges. As knowledge of plant biology increases, the field will progress from informatics-based discovery to predictive modeling and eventually to synthetic biology. A comprehensive CI that eliminates the bottlenecks of data management, data standards, file formats, analysis, efficient collaboration, and knowledge dissemination will be a necessary underlying enabler to achieve this vision, and iPlant is positioned to be this enabling infrastructure.   

The broader impacts of the project are numerous. The CI currently supports thousands of  end users through its data storage, cloud, and online analytical capabilities. As a service provider, iPlant underlies a number of other online biological information resources. The project will continue its wide-ranging and successful education and outreach efforts, and will teach computational skills to learners at all levels, with particular focus on faculty to enable a sustained culture change that incorporates these advanced skills into the teaching of biology.

por.por_cntn:
CyVerse, formerly the iPlant Collaborative, is funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) to create an innovative, comprehensive, generic, and foundational cyberinfrastructure (CI) in support of life sciences research. CyVerse?s CI uniquely enables researchers in the diverse life science domains to address Science Grand Challenges in novel ways, to attempt and achieve cross-disciplinary and collaborative research, to use cutting-edge computer science research methods, and to develop communities of practice centered around data-driven discoveries. 

With an expanded mandate to serve the life sciences, iPlant updated its mission statement, taglines, and relevant media in 2013. As iPlant struggled to disseminate the message of its expanded scope beyond the plant science community, the name CyVerse, a hybridization of ?cyber? and ?universe,? was selected in 2015 to emphasize that the project is a globally accessible cyberinfrastructure for scientists to explore the universe. The new name and messaging now convey CyVerse?s broadened scope to diverse scientific, software development, and education audiences. 

Key outcomes from this project period were achieved through developing the cyberinfrastructure itself, as well as engaging and training the life sciences community.

Engaging the Life Science Community

CyVerse was built to enable data-driven discovery across the life sciences ? from immunobiology and cancer research to ecology and plant sciences. Immunobiologists are using CyVerse to push the boundaries of cancer research: CyVerse data sharing and high-performance computing technology are helping to comprehensively map the human adaptive immune system. 

Similarly, the lack of analyses and databases for microbiologists to study viruses had created a bottleneck for understanding viruses and the microbes they infect. Powered by CyVerse, researchers developed iVirus, a web-based platform for viral ecology research. The group?s instructional videos, computational tools and workflows provide viral ecologists with web-based resources their community needs to collaborate, share data and gain knowledge to spur scientific advances.

The Cyberinfrastructure

CyVerse has expanded in both the number of user accounts and amount of data deposited in its CI. Total user accounts in 2019 exceeded 70,000, a 617% increase from the beginning of the project. Scientists continue to leverage CyVerse capabilities for data sharing with their collaborators. During this project period, the Data Store gained 3.7 PB of new data, up from the 3.3 PB stored in 2013. Researchers moved more than 10 PB of data in CyVerse in just the last two years of the project period.

In addition, CyVerse core technologies were adopted and deployed in other scientific disciplines and applications, magnifying the impact of CyVerse?s scientific enablement. The Massachusetts Open Cloud Consortium, XSEDE JetStream, and CloudLab use CyVerse Atmosphere to manage their cloud systems. In partnership with the Renaissance Computing Institute, the Discovery Environment has been installed for social science data analysis, hydrology research (HydroShaPare), and brain imaging research in mice. The CyVerse?s Science APIs (later Agave API) were used by the Centers for Disease Control for threat detection and by structural and civil engineers, DesignSafe, for simulation and modeling. The Data Store enables open data through its use as a central data hub for Astrolabe, an open access repository for sharing astronomical datasets; MagAO, an adaptive optics system for Chile?s Magellan telescope; the Southern Ocean Carbon and Climate Observations and Modeling (SOCCOM) project to unlock the mysteries of the southern ocean and its influence on climate; and DOE ARPA-E projects, TERRA and ROOTS, for plant phenotyping. Through federation, NASA MERRA data are now available for use by earth scientists. 

The entire CyVerse infrastructure is sufficiently robust to deploy for new scientific purposes such as Space Object Behaviors and in high data security environments (NIST 181-700 ITAR/CUI compliance) for defense work and managing clinical patient data. The UK and Austria have deployed local installations of CyVerse infrastructure, with Australia, India, Chile, and Brazil planning similar deployments.

Training Scientists

CyVerse is training the next generation of computationally-savvy life scientists, enabling communities of practice to arise. Through diverse efforts such as workshops, webinars, outreach at professional meetings, support of faculty teaching at primarily undergraduate-serving institutions (PUIs), and working directly to empower individual community members to achieve their research, development, and educational agendas, CyVerse is building capacity in the research workforce to expertly use computational resources like CyVerse for science discovery.

Students and postdocs account for approximately 60% of CyVerse users. Partnering with Data and Software Carpentry on workshops has enhanced CyVerse?s ability to prepare this audience to embark on their first big data analyses. CyVerse also has begun offering training in intermediate technologies such as containers and open science. These provide students and early career researchers with vital skills to advance their personal research agendas, find employment, and implement robust data management plans.
